The storm is coming: Here’s exactly what I’m doing with my portfolio right now
==============================================================================

**After 40 years on Wall Street, I’m seeing all the warning signs again**
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

[![Image 5: Michael Schwarz](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*rRyT9dnB6hsKtYxT31YJVg.jpeg)](https://msfinance1955.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--4da7503db849---------------------------------------)

[Michael Schwarz](https://msfinance1955.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--4da7503db849---------------------------------------)

Follow

6 min read

·

Aug 13, 2025

[](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fvote%2Finsiderfinance%2F4da7503db849&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwire.insiderfinance.io%2Fthe-storm-is-coming-heres-exactly-what-i-m-doing-with-my-portfolio-right-now-4da7503db849&user=Michael+Schwarz&userId=6947385d7f5d&source=---header_actions--4da7503db849---------------------clap_footer------------------)

4.1K

108

[](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fbookmark%2Fp%2F4da7503db849&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwire.insiderfinance.io%2Fthe-storm-is-coming-heres-exactly-what-i-m-doing-with-my-portfolio-right-now-4da7503db849&source=---header_actions--4da7503db849---------------------bookmark_footer------------------)

[Listen](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2Fplans%3Fdimension%3Dpost_audio_button%26postId%3D4da7503db849&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwire.insiderfinance.io%2Fthe-storm-is-coming-heres-exactly-what-i-m-doing-with-my-portfolio-right-now-4da7503db849&source=---header_actions--4da7503db849---------------------post_audio_button------------------)

Share

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 6: 3D bar chart with rising white bars and a red arrow showing growth followed by a sharp decline, representing a market correction](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/0*WUMhtkgAfdQVU5Nx.jpg)

Illustration of a market correction. Google images

Listen, I’ve been through this dance before. Seven times, to be exact. From the 1987 crash to the dot com bubble, from 2008 to the COVID plunge. And right now, sitting here in my home office looking at the same charts I’ve been watching since the 1980s, I’m seeing those familiar patterns forming again.

But here’s the thing: I’m not panicking. And neither should you.

Why I think a correction is coming
----------------------------------

After four decades of watching markets breathe in and out like a living thing, you develop a feel for when things are getting stretched too thin. Right now, the S&P 500 is trading at valuations that make my old risk models flash red. We’re seeing PE ratios north of 30 for companies that haven’t turned a profit in years. Sound familiar? It should.

The Fed has been playing tough with interest rates, and while everyone’s been celebrating the AI boom, nobody’s talking about the elephant in the room: corporate earnings are starting to miss expectations. When Amazon and Apple start giving cautious guidance, I pay attention. When small caps are getting crushed while mega caps keep climbing, that’s not a healthy market. That’s a market standing on one leg.

Plus, my old colleagues at the big banks are all whispering the same thing over lunch: their risk departments are pulling back. When Goldman and Morgan Stanley start getting conservative with their own money, you know something’s up.

What I’m actually doing with my own money
-----------------------------------------

Alright, cards on the table. Here’s exactly what I did with my portfolio last week, and what I’m planning to do over the next month.

First off, I took profits on my big tech winners. I sold about 40% of my highest flying positions. Yeah, they might keep going up, but you know what? Pigs get fat, hogs get slaughtered. I learned that lesson the hard way in 1999 when I held onto my tech darlings too long. Those 200% and 300% gains I’m sitting on? I’m perfectly happy to lock in some of them now.

I’m also rotating into boring stuff. I know, I know, nobody wants to hear about utilities and consumer staples when growth stocks are going to the moon. But when the correction comes, and it will come, my defensive positions are going to look like genius moves. I’m buying companies that sell toothpaste, electricity, and groceries. These businesses were around before I started my career, and they’ll be around long after I’m gone.

Cash is not trash right now. I’ve moved about 25% of my portfolio to cash and short term treasuries. With rates where they are, I’m getting 5% basically risk free. During the last three corrections, having dry powder to deploy was the difference between retiring comfortably and retiring wealthy. When everyone else is selling in a panic, that’s when you go shopping.

**Building a foundation before the storm hits**
-----------------------------------------------

You know what? Before I tell you about the tactical moves for this correction, let me share something more important. The best defense against any market storm isn’t timing or clever trades. It’s having a rock solid, low cost index fund core that you never have to worry about.

In my guide, **Investing the Bogle way: A simple guide for the long term investor**, I lay out the exact framework I’ve used through seven market corrections. How to build that boring but beautiful portfolio of index funds, the right asset allocation for your age, setting up automatic rebalancing so you don’t have to think about it, and most importantly, how to stay calm when everyone else is losing their minds. It’s 49 pages of no nonsense advice. You can read a free two chapter preview first to see if it’s your style:

[Get 2-chapter preview for free! ------------------------------- ### Investing the Bogle way: After four decades in the world of investing, I've seen what works, and more importantly, what doesn't. This guide is… msfinance1955.gumroad.com](https://msfinance1955.gumroad.com/l/investing-the-bogle-way?utm_source=medium&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=storm_is_coming_aug25&source=post_page-----4da7503db849---------------------------------------)

The moves that could save your retirement
-----------------------------------------

Look, I get it. You’ve probably got a 401k, maybe some individual stocks, perhaps a bit of crypto because your friends told you to buy some. Here’s what you need to do, and you need to do it soon.

Rebalance your portfolio now, not later. If tech stocks make up more than 40% of your holdings, you’re playing with fire. I’m not saying sell everything, but trim it back to 25% or 30%. Take those profits and spread them around. Buy some international stocks, add some bonds, get some real estate exposure through REITs.

Get Michael Schwarz’s stories in your inbox
-------------------------------------------

Join Medium for free to get updates from this writer.

Subscribe

Subscribe

Stop checking your account every day. Seriously. One of the biggest mistakes I see regular folks make is watching their portfolio like it’s a sports game. Set up your defensive positions, then go live your life. The market will do what it’s going to do whether you’re watching or not.

Consider dollar cost averaging in reverse. Instead of dumping everything at once, sell your positions gradually over the next few weeks. Same idea when the correction happens and you want to get back in. Don’t try to catch a falling knife. Spread your purchases out over months.

What NOT to do right now
------------------------

Whatever you do, don’t go all cash. I’ve seen too many people sell everything, then watch the market go up another 20% and buy back in at the top. That’s a great way to turn a winning portfolio into a losing one. Stay invested, just be smart about it.

Don’t buy puts or try to short the market unless you really, really know what you’re doing. I’ve been doing this for 40 years and I still get my tail handed to me when I try to time the market perfectly. The market can stay irrational longer than you can stay solvent, as my old boss used to say.

And please, please don’t lever up thinking you’re going to make a killing on the way down. I saw too many smart people blow up their accounts in 2008 trying to be clever with options and margin. This isn’t the time to be a hero.

The silver lining nobody talks about
------------------------------------

Here’s something the financial media won’t tell you: corrections are actually good for long term investors. They’re like forest fires that clear out the dead wood and let new growth flourish. Every single correction in my career has been followed by new highs, eventually.

If you’re under 50, you should be praying for a correction. Seriously. You want to be buying stocks when they’re on sale, not when they’re priced for perfection. The money I made buying during the 2008 crisis set me up for the retirement I’m enjoying now.

Even if you’re closer to my age, a 20% correction isn’t the end of the world if you’re properly positioned. It’s an opportunity to upgrade your portfolio, swap out the weak players for the strong ones, and position yourself for the next bull run.

My final thoughts after four decades
------------------------------------

You want to know the truth? I’m kind of excited about what’s coming. Not because I want to see people lose money, but because corrections separate the investors from the gamblers. They remind us that trees don’t grow to the sky, and that risk is real.

I’ve survived and thrived through every major market event since Reagan was president. The key isn’t to predict exactly when the correction will happen or how deep it will go. The key is to be prepared for it, to not panic when it arrives, and to have the courage to act when everyone else is frozen with fear.

So here’s my advice, the same advice I’m giving my own kids: Take some profits, raise some cash, diversify your holdings, and then relax. The market will correct, it always does. But if you’re prepared for it, you’ll come out the other side stronger than ever.

_Disclaimer: This article is for informational purposes only and should not be considered financial advice. Do your own research or consult a professional before making investment decisions._

The analysis of topographic 3D and 4D point clouds has become essential across various scientific disciplines, including geosciences, environmental studies, ecology, archaeology, and robotics.

To address the growing need for effective change detection in these datasets, the open-source library **py4dgeo** has been developed, offering robust tools for multitemporal point cloud analysis.

### **Overview of py4dgeo**

py4dgeo is a C++ library with Python bindings, designed to facilitate change analysis in multitemporal and 4D point clouds. The library integrates seamlessly into Python workflows, making it accessible for researchers and professionals working with geospatial data.

### **Key Features**

*   **M3C2 Algorithm**: The library implements the Multiscale Model to Model Cloud Comparison (M3C2) algorithm, enabling precise distance computations between bitemporal point clouds. This method is widely recognized for its accuracy in detecting changes over time.

Prompted by Mohamed Bakry using ChatGPT

AI isn’t just another productivity tool.. It’s the bridge between imagination and reality.

Picture yourself at your laptop in a warm-lit workspace, icons of productivity floating around you. That’s not fantasy — it’s the opportunity to scale up and work at a higher level with AI.

And the data backs it up. A Forbes Advisor survey found that 64% of U.S. business owners believe AI boosts productivity and customer relationships.

Additionally, 60% expect it to raise sales, and nearly 59% predict cost savings.

Senior execs driving growth strategies rely 65% on AI and predictive tools. Over 50% of them see faster ideation and content production already.

After many hours with ChatGPT, I found the right prompts. They can turn AI into your personal product factory.

These prompts aren’t just generic one-liners. They are expert-grade and designed to fill real gaps in today’s market.

_After building 12 real applications with 23 different AI tools, I discovered which ones actually deliver on their promises (and which ones are just hype)_

The AI development tool space is exploding. Every week, there’s a new “revolutionary” platform promising to 10x developer productivity, eliminate bugs, or write perfect code automatically. But here’s the problem: **most of them are garbage**.

As a developer who’s been burned by overhyped tools before, I decided to put these claims to the test. Over 30 days, I built 12 real applications using 23 different AI development tools, spending $847 of my own money and 240+ hours of testing.

**The results shocked me.**

Some tools that get massive hype barely work. Others that fly under the radar are absolutely game-changing. And a few are so good they’ve permanently changed how I write code.

Here’s everything I learned, with real data, actual code examples, and honest assessments of what works and what doesn’t.

My Testing Methodology (Because Most Reviews Are Useless)
---------------------------------------------------------

How to Make a DIY AI Workstation on the Cheap
=============================================

[![Image 4: Aeon Flex, Elriel Assoc. 2133 [NEON MAXIMA]](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*ewo3-1c0qY57bCDWa3tdUA.png)](http://medium.com/@neonmaxima?source=post_page---byline--88e3abd99be5---------------------------------------)

Why Build Instead of Rent
-------------------------

If you have ever tried running Stable Diffusion or playing with a large language model on your own computer, you already know how fast your laptop fan starts sounding like a jet engine. The common advice you will hear online is to “just use Colab” or “rent an A100 from the cloud.”

That works for quick tests, but cloud services are not designed for everyday tinkering. They:

*   **Charge by the hour** for GPU time.
*   **Throttle or ban accounts** if you run resource-heavy scripts.
*   **Depend on connectivity**. If your WiFi goes out, so does your work.
*   **Take your data off your machine**, which is not ideal if you are training anything sensitive.

A local AI workstation flips this equation. You pay once for hardware, you own the entire pipeline, and you learn a lot more by maintaining the system yourself. Plus, there is something deeply satisfying about running a 13B model on hardware you resurrected from e-waste.

Step 1: The Hardware Philosophy
-------------------------------

When you build a DIY AI rig, the mindset is different from building a gaming PC. Gamers chase frame rates. AI tinkerers chase stability and memory bandwidth.

The key is balance:

*   **CPU** does preprocessing and data handling.
*   **GPU** crunches tensors.
*   **RAM** keeps models from choking when they load.
*   **Storage** holds datasets and checkpoints.

It is not about having the newest shiny gear. It is about knowing which bottleneck will hit you first and solving it without overpaying.

**ThinkPads** and **refurbished desktops** shine here because they were engineered for reliability, not fashion. A ThinkPad keyboard has survived more spills and drops than any MacBook I have seen. An old Dell tower has a boring gray chassis, but plenty of airflow for a mid-tier GPU.

*   [Lenovo ThinkPad T480 (Refurbished](https://amzn.to/45YfOeI))
*   [Dell Optiplex 7060 Tower (Refurbished)](https://amzn.to/3HJ9deS)

Step 2: The Realistic Limits
----------------------------

Let’s be clear. You are not going to train GPT-4 at home. But here is what you actually can do on a modest DIY build:

*   Run [**Stable Diffusion**](https://stabledifffusion.com/) locally for art generation.
*   Fine-tune a [**7B parameter LLaMA derivative**](https://huggingface.co/MBZUAI/bactrian-x-llama-7b-lora) with LoRA adapters.
*   Experiment with [**Whisper**](https://openai.com/index/whisper/) for voice-to-text.
*   Chain small models with [**LangChain**](https://www.langchain.com/) to simulate agents.

That covers 95% of what indie developers and hobbyists actually want to try. The dream of “training a trillion-parameter model in your garage” is marketing hype. The real game is smart, efficient use of local resources.

Step 3: The Upgrade Path
------------------------

Here is the strategic way to breathe new life into old gear:

**Start with RAM** — Go to 16GB minimum, 32GB if possible.

**Replace the HDD with SSD** — The speed jump is not cosmetic. Model loading time drops from minutes to seconds.

*   [Crucial MX500 1TB SSD](https://amzn.to/47E8czp)

**Add a GPU if possible** —A 3060 with 12GB VRAM is the sweet spot.

*   [NVIDIA RTX 3060 12GB](https://amzn.to/41dl0sE)

Why not chase a 3090 or 4090? Because they guzzle power, generate absurd heat, and cost as much as an entire refurbished workstation. A 3060 is the line where affordability intersects with usefulness.

Step 4: Installing Linux Without Tears
--------------------------------------

The part that scares most people is Linux. But if you can install Windows, you can install Ubuntu or Pop!_OS.

Subscribe

**Tips from experience:**

*   Always check your GPU driver version matches your CUDA toolkit.
*   Use `nvidia-smi` in the terminal to confirm the GPU is recognized.
*   Use Conda or Venv to isolate environments. Mixing dependencies is how most beginners break their installs.

My advice: keep a simple text log of commands you run. You will thank yourself later when you break something and need to retrace your steps.

Step 5: Setting Up AI Frameworks
--------------------------------

The big two are PyTorch and TensorFlow. PyTorch has become the standard in research and open-source projects, so start there.

Installation (assuming you have CUDA set up):

pip install torch torchvision torchaudio --extra-index-url https://d ownload.pytorch.org/whl/cu118
Then grab your tools:

*   **Stable Diffusion WebUI** for generating images.
*   **Ollama** or **LM Studio** for running LLMs locally.
*   **LangChain** if you want to build agents.

Each has active communities, which is worth more than documentation. When you hit a wall, you will need Discords, forums, or GitHub Issues threads to lean on.

Step 6: Real-Life Caveats Nobody Tells You
------------------------------------------

This is where a lot of YouTube tutorials gloss over reality.

*   **Heat management** — Old machines run hot. Keep an eye on temps or you will fry your GPU.
*   [_A $20 cooling pad is cheaper than replacing parts._](https://amzn.to/3Joi1rd)
*   **Power draw** — Desktops with GPUs can spike at 300–500W. Know your breaker limits.
*   **Noise** — Refurbished towers with stock fans are loud. If you work in a small room, consider upgrading to quieter fans.
*   **Disk space creep** — Model checkpoints eat storage like candy. Plan for at least 1TB if you want to collect models.

Step 7: Sample Projects to Try Once You’re Set Up
-------------------------------------------------

1.   **Personal Research Assistant**

 Run a 7B model locally with your own PDFs fed in for retrieval-augmented Q&A.
2.   **Voice-to-Text Logger**

 Use Whisper to transcribe your own recordings and pipe them into a searchable database.
3.   **Custom Art Tool**

 Fine-tune Stable Diffusion on your own dataset of textures or logos for unique designs.
4.   **Offline Chatbot**

 A local Ollama instance means no API calls and no surveillance.

Step 8: Optional Future Expansions
----------------------------------

*   **eGPU Setup for ThinkPads** — [Razer Core X eGPU Enclosure](https://amzn.to/4lwpFNp) lets you attach a full-size GPU externally.
*   **Dedicated NAS for Datasets** — Store your models and training data separately.
*   **Secondhand Quadro Cards** — For those who prefer workstation-grade reliability over gaming cards.

Final Thoughts
--------------

The cheapest way to learn AI is not by renting someone else’s GPU. It is by taking a humble ThinkPad or a discarded Dell tower and bending it into a tool that works for you.

Cloud is convenient. DIY is permanent.

When you maintain your own rig you are not just saving money. You are building technical literacy in hardware, operating systems, and software environments. These are skills that compound. And you are keeping old machines alive instead of feeding the endless consumer cycle.

Never Use a Calculator for Square Roots Again
=============================================

Square Roots Made Ridiculously Fast — 5 Seconds
-----------------------------------------------

Image by the author

You’re in a math contest. You have 5 seconds to find the square root of **9604**— no calculator allowed.

What would you do?

Maybe you’d guess. Maybe you’d try numbers whose squares seem close to 9604, hoping to zero in on the answer.

But chances are, you’d waste precious seconds… and possibly get it wrong.

Let me show you a trick I recently learned — a simple mental shortcut for finding square roots of large numbers, especially 4- or 5-digit ones.

For this trick, if you already know the squares of the numbers from 1 to 9, you’re good to go.That’s all you need!

Ready?

Let’s go!

We’ll begin with the last digit — 4

Which one-digit numbers have squares that end in 4?

**2 and 8**

2 squared gives 4, and 8 squared gives 64. Both of them end in 4.

Cool!

Now let’s ignore the last two digits of 9604 — that is, we focus only on the 96.

What number gives the closest square to 96, without going over?

> _“The future is already here — it’s just not evenly distributed.” — William Gibson_

The Rise and Stall of Web3
--------------------------

Web3 was supposed to be the decentralized savior of the internet. It promised:

*   User ownership through tokens
*   Decentralized apps (dApps)
*   Autonomous governance via DAOs

Yet here we are in 2025, and the dream feels more like a stalled beta than a revolution.

![Image 5](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:576/1*bNaj4vFrG1vHmhoGq7Hjjg.avif)

Image used under fair use. Sourced from Google. Not owned by the author.

**What went wrong?**

*   **Tokenomics fatigue**: Too many projects with vague utility and volatile coins.
*   **UX nightmares**: Wallets, gas fees, bridges — still confusing to the average user.
*   **Centralized dependencies**: Many dApps still rely on Web2 infrastructure (AWS, Google Cloud).

Meanwhile, Web5 Quietly Arrived
-------------------------------

Web5 isn’t a next version in numerical sequence; it’s a leap.

Coined and initiated by TBD (a division of Block), Web5 is an open-source vision focused on **decentralized identity and data ownership**.

**No tokens. No hype. Just protocols.**

Qwen-Image-Edit : Best AI model for image editing
=================================================

How to use Qwen-Image-Edit for free?
------------------------------------

[![Image 16: Mehul Gupta](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:32:32/1*vyvhK_h4zA05mg_Y-n2qBA.jpeg)](http://medium.com/@mehulgupta_7991?source=post_page---byline--1b3386628ef7---------------------------------------)

![Image 17](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1000/0*y_pkUODGb8h-CjSR)

So Qwen released something called **Qwen-Image-Edit**. It’s an image editing model built on top of their 20B Qwen-Image foundation. That means it’s not a separate tool from scratch, just an extension of a system that already knew how to understand and generate images, including stuff like text rendering.

Press enter or click to view image in full size![Image 18](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1280/0*h4RSszvho8Nbk5v7)

Press enter or click to view image in full size![Image 19](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1280/0*rukMEPzv9LGcXqEi)

> **But here’s the thing:**this model isn’t just “good at drawing” or “can change a cat into a dog.”

It actually handles **two** difficult types of edits well:

1.   **Semantic Edits :**changing what the image _means_ (turning a portrait into an anime version, rotating objects to show a new side, swapping styles)
2.   **Appearance Edits :**modifying small parts without touching the rest (like removing a lamp post but keeping shadows consistent, or changing shirt color without bleeding into the face)

Press enter or click to view image in full size![Image 20](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1280/0*dQSkISxg-fkRZTER)

Press enter or click to view image in full size![Image 21](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1280/0*UDDRa6g1Jc75-nub)

**_And it does both in one shot. That’s rare. Most tools only do one or the other, or require heavy prompting and retries._**

How It Works Internally (Simplified)
------------------------------------

Press enter or click to view image in full size![Image 22](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1280/0*FU08nP4WqOAQ2TWZ)

Press enter or click to view image in full size![Image 23](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1280/0*pU6PGq4bsKCFTVss)

Qwen-Image-Edit doesn’t just throw the image into one model and pray. It feeds the image into two different systems:

*   **Qwen2.5-VL** :which handles the meaning or semantics of the image (like “this is a dog,” “this is the front side,” etc.)
*   **VAE Encoder** : which focuses on the appearance and textures (the actual pixels: edges, color, lighting)

> This dual-path approach means you can tell it to _rotate a car 180 degrees_ and it’ll understand not just the object but also how the back of it should _look_. Or tell it to _add a signboard_, and it’ll throw in the correct _reflection_ too, which is honestly nuts.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 24](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/0*g1piGmv5TTX6MZMu)

Editing Text in Images
----------------------

Press enter or click to view image in full size![Image 25](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1280/0*5QJC-UddDLW3Z8as)

Press enter or click to view image in full size![Image 26](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1280/0*Q6XhHIWXpwKolZ5R)

Most image models fail miserably at editing text. Either the font looks off, the alignment breaks, or it smudges everything. Qwen-Image-Edit doesn’t. You can:

*   **Add text**
*   **Delete text**
*   **Modify specific characters**

…and it keeps the _original font_, size, and style. It works on **both English and Chinese** text. That’s a big deal if you’re working on posters, documents, labels, etc.

> You can even highlight just a part of the image, say, one letter in a word, and tell it: “make this blue.” It’ll change just that part without affecting anything else.

Real Use Cases
--------------

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 27](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/0*f_C_UE2jy-VTOSdm)

Let’s break down what it can _actually_ be used for, with examples:

---------------------------------------

Subscribe

Subscribe

**1. Character Editing**

They tested it on their Capybara mascot, editing it across 16 MBTI personality types. That means generating different moods, poses, and styles while keeping the “core” character intact. Most pixels change. The identity doesn’t. That’s the “semantic consistency” part.

**2. Viewpoint Control**

You can rotate objects in images: 90 degrees, 180 degrees, etc. And it doesn’t just flip the pixels, it shows you the actual back view, constructed based on the object’s logic. This opens up a lot of possibilities in product visualization, AR/VR design, etc.

**3. Style Transfer**

Take a regular photo, ask for a specific art style, say, Ghibli, and Qwen handles it. No artifacts. No strange borders. The face, expression, and lighting stay consistent with the new style.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 28](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/0*C5bBWQYpRfs1SIHV)

**4. Spot Removal**

Want to erase tiny hairs from a photo? Or delete unwanted background clutter without affecting shadows or edges? This model does that cleanly. And it doesn’t touch nearby elements unless you tell it to.

**5. Background / Clothing Change**

It supports isolated edits like swapping someone’s shirt color or changing the background behind them, without messing with skin tones or lighting on the face.

**6. Multi-step Fixes (like in calligraphy correction)**

There’s an interesting example where they generated a Chinese calligraphy piece that had a few wrong characters. So they fixed it using **chained edits,**first correcting the broad character shape, then drilling down to individual radicals or strokes. You could even highlight one section and say “fix just this,” and it responds accordingly.

### That kind of fine-grained control is hard to get right. Most AI tools blur or over-correct. This one lets you move in steps.

How to use Qwen-Image-Edit for free?
------------------------------------

The model weights are open-sourced and is accessible below

[Qwen/Qwen-Image-Edit · Hugging Face ----------------------------------- ### We're on a journey to advance and democratize artificial intelligence through open source and open science. huggingface.co](https://huggingface.co/Qwen/Qwen-Image-Edit?source=post_page-----1b3386628ef7---------------------------------------)

The model can be tested for free here

[Qwen Chat --------- ### Qwen Chat offers comprehensive functionality spanning chatbot, image and video understanding, image generation… chat.qwen.ai](https://chat.qwen.ai/?source=post_page-----1b3386628ef7---------------------------------------)

It Actually Performs Well
-------------------------

They benchmarked it across public image editing datasets and it beats the other foundation models. There’s no marketing jargon here, they just say it performs better and demonstrate it with examples. It’s not trying to be “creative.” It’s trying to be _reliable_.

There are dozens of “image editing” AIs out there. Most are good for social media fun, but when you need to do **real, controlled, undoable, localized edits**, they fall apart.

Qwen-Image-Edit doesn’t. It takes instructions seriously. It knows what part to change and what to leave untouched. It handles text properly. It can do chained corrections. It gets both _what_ you’re trying to do and _how_ the result should look.

And finally, it’s already live on Qwen Chat under the “Image Editing” feature. Try it out. If you’ve struggled with AI-generated noise before, this one might actually feel like a breath of fresh air.

You ever ask a question just for fun… and instantly regret it?

> Yeah. That was me with GPT-5.

I wanted a quick “lol” moment.

Instead?

It gave me a digital slap across the face and basically said: “Brace yourself, 2026 isn’t what you think.”

> Everyone Thinks the Future Is Shiny

> **Flying cars.**
> 
> 
> **AI butlers.**
> 
> 
> **More time, more money, more vibes.**

> Reality: That’s not what 2026 looks like.

**We’re not heading into a utopia. We’re diving headfirst into an identity crisis.**

And GPT-5 didn’t sugarcoat it.

1. Work? What Work?
-------------------

> “What jobs will be in demand in 2026?”

My innocent question.

GPT-5’s answer?

> **“Mostly the ones AI hasn’t stolen yet.”**

Cool. So we’re playing career dodgeball now.

Title: The Best AI Video Generators: A Detailed Comparison of 10 Tools

URL Source: http://medium.com/@jimclydemonge/the-best-ai-video-generators-a-detailed-comparison-of-10-tools-05baf1039031

Published Time: 2025-08-19T02:52:54Z

Markdown Content:
Here are 10 of the best AI video generator tools you should know about.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

[![Image 1: Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*y21asU2FcaTTiDiyXbJK9A.jpeg)](https://jimclydemonge.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--05baf1039031---------------------------------------)

13 min read

Aug 19, 2025

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 2: The Best AI Video Generator: A Detailed Comparison of 10 Tools](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*A0ZwqdLj7YLsDQdi7d1FSQ.jpeg)

Best AI video generators in 2025. Image by 

AI video tech has come a long way in just a couple of years. Back in 2023, most of the AI video clips I generated with models like Kling or Stable Video Diffusion looked mushy, robotic, and obviously fake.

Fast forward to 2025, and we now have models that generate footage realistic enough to fool the average viewer. These tools can recreate natural human movement, faces that express genuine emotion, and even sound that matches perfectly with the scene.

But with this progress comes a new problem: CHOICE.

There are now hundreds of video models, both open-source and proprietary, and just as many platforms to choose from. For creators, businesses, or developers, picking the right one can be overwhelming.

That’s why I put this guide together. In this article, I’ll compare ten of the most popular AI video generators today. To be fair to all the platforms and easily see their differences, I will be using a common prompt to generate the AI videos:

> **Prompt:**A young woman sits by the window of a cozy coffee shop at sunset, sipping her coffee while looking outside. The warm orange glow of the setting sun floods the shop, casting soft golden light on her face and reflecting off the glass. Outside the window, people walk by slowly, and the city street glows with the fading light of the day. The coffee shop interior has wooden tables, plants, and hanging lights that flicker softly. The scene feels cinematic, with a gentle camera pan across the room, highlighting the peaceful mood.

Here’s a quick summary of the tools:

1.   [Pollo AI](https://pollo.ai/)
2.   Google Veo 3 (Gemini)
3.   Kling 2.1 Master
4.   Runway Gen 4
5.   OpenAI Sora
6.   Hailuo AI
7.   Pika Labs
8.   Invideo AI
9.   Adobe Firefly
10.   HeyGen

I’ll break down their features, strengths, and pricing, so you can figure out which platform actually fits your workflow.

Let’s get started.

### 1. Pollo AI

[Pollo AI](https://pollo.ai/) is a platform for generating both AI images and videos. It supports some of the most capable models out there, including Flux, GPT-Image-1, Imagen 4, Veo 3, Kling 2.1, and several others.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 3: Pollo AI. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*V5Z5mmuRRT7B-GcjWxoqDw.png)

Pollo AI. Image by 

To get started, create an account and open the AI Video tab. Under the models dropdown, select your preferred video model. In this example, I will be using Hailuo 02. Paste the prompt in the text field and configure all the required video settings.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 4: Pollo AI text-to-video. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*X7Va9_lguyPk6ourxNCYjQ.png)

Pollo AI text-to-video. Image by 

Click on the Create button and wait for the video to be generated. Here’s the final result:

Pollo AI text-to-video sample output. Image by 

Awesome! The video generation only took ~30 seconds, and the video is a 720p 6-second MP4 file.

**Pricing**

Pollo AI offers two plans:

*   Lite at $15 per month (300 credits, 30 videos)
*   Pro at $29 per month (800 credits, 80 videos)

You can also save 50% by paying yearly. Both plans include multi-model support, image and video generation, templates, and effects, with Pro giving more credits and parallel tasks.

**My Observations**

I love how intuitive and easy to use Pollo AI is. It supports most of the powerful video models out there, and the generation is fast and cheap. The image generator tool is also handy because you can create input images for image-to-video models without leaving the platform. On top of that, there’s a list of extra AI tools like a video upscaler, enhancer, face swap, and more, which makes it even more useful.

### 2. Google Veo 3 (Gemini)

Veo 3 is the latest and most capable video model from Google. It doesn’t just generate realistic videos. It delivers higher resolution, stronger physics understanding, better prompt adherence, and even built-in audio support.

You can try Veo 3 in Google Flow, the Gemini app, Vertex AI, or through third-party API providers like Fal AI and Replicate.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 5: Google Veo 3 (Gemini). Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*wz1JJR2uR8lzfgSvvCkwYQ.png)

Google Veo 3 (Gemini). Image by 

Using the same coffee shop at sunset prompt, I brought up Gemini and generated the video using Veo 3:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 6: Google Veo 3 (Gemini) prompt example. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*9HMpYjLblP3kRRq_4nIlug.png)

Google Veo 3 (Gemini) prompt example. Image by 

Here’s the final video:

Google Veo 3 (Gemini) output example. Image by 

The lighting looks natural, the reflections on the window look real, and the motion was smoother compared to other models.

**Pricing**

Veo 3 is included in the Gemini Pro subscription with limited access. Through APIs, it costs around $3.75 for an 8-second video. Veo 3 Fast is a cheaper option, usually around $2 for a 5-second video.

**My Observations**

Veo 3 is the go-to model for creators and marketers who need the highest quality. The native audio generation is a big plus. But it’s also the most expensive option right now, so it’s not ideal if you’re on a tight budget. If you have the budget and want premium results, it’s probably the best choice available.

### 3. Kling 2.1 Master

Kling is one of the most popular and powerful AI video generators out there. It was one of the first platforms to offer video generation back in 2023, and it has continued to evolve. The latest release, Kling 2.1 Master, is their most capable model so far.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 7: Kling 2.1 homepage. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*zt1-QyPMvSTuqabxZsVeZA.png)

Kling 2.1 homepage. Image by 

Alongside video generation, the platform also supports image generation, image editing, and even sound effects creation.

Using the coffee shop at sunset prompt, Kling 2.1 Master generated a clean and vibrant clip with good lighting and smoother character motion compared to older versions.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 8: Kling 2.1 master video generator. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*ssCinbmDTUWZFdCHZy3Szw.png)

Kling 2.1 master video generator. Image by 

Here’s what the final video looks like:

Kling 2.1 master video sample. Image by 

**Pricing**

Subscriptions start as low as $6.99, making it one of the most affordable options. You can also scale up by purchasing more credits, with plans going as high as $1200 for heavy users.

**My Observations**

Kling 2.1 offers a substantial upgrade over Kling 2.0. The jump in resolution and overall video quality is noticeable. However, it still doesn’t reach the same level of realism as Veo 3, but it delivers impressive results for its price.

### 4. Runway Gen 4

Runway’s Gen-4 is the latest version of their AI video model, and it’s one of the most interesting tools on this list. It’s built for creators who care about consistency across shots and scenes. That means you can keep the same character or object across multiple shots without retraining or doing complex tweaks.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 9: Runway ML homepage. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*nzNzF6rNR2D9eAShmyU-HQ.png)

Runway ML homepage. Image by 

Using the coffee shop at sunset prompt, I plugged it into the video generator dashboard and uploaded a reference image.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 10: Runway Gen4 dashboard. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*MZoyFzo-ScnOIgi1eBt0OA.png)

Runway Gen4 dashboard. Image by 

Here’s what the output video looks like:

Runway Gen4 sample output. Image by 

The lighting was cinematic, and the character looked consistent across different camera angles. It wasn’t as sharp as Veo 3 in realism, but it stood out with smooth transitions that made it feel like part of a longer sequence.

**Pricing**

Runway starts at $15 per editor per month when billed monthly, with 20% off if you go yearly. The Standard plan gives access to all models, including Aleph (video editing), Gen-4 (image and video), and Act-Two. You also get watermark removal, 4K upscaling, shorter wait times, and 625 credits monthly.

Credits translate to about 125s of Gen-4 Turbo, 52s of Gen-4, or more for earlier models. Extra credits can be purchased if needed.

**My Observations**

Gen-4 is strong when it comes to stylized content, including anime-style videos. Runway itself is packed with editing and generation tools, which means you can build entire short films without leaving the platform. The downside is that it’s not cheap, and rendering times can vary depending on complexity.

### 5. OpenAI Sora

Sora is OpenAI’s AI video generation tool that creates short clips from text, images, or even other videos. With the Sora Video Editor, you can generate videos up to 20 seconds long while keeping good visual quality and following your prompt closely.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 11: OpenAI Sora homepage. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*YUAXKTkP4zYmOxmwOuV8dg.png)

OpenAI Sora homepage. Image by 

To create a video, just set the mode to video and enter your prompt. You can also play with the other video configurations like the aspect ratio, resolution, and duration.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 12: OpenAI Sora promt. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*IRcSOQvE-VUnSsiszL3t7Q.png)

OpenAI Sora prompt. Image by 

Here’s what I got in the end:

OpenAI Sora sample output. Image by 

**Pricing**

Sora is included in ChatGPT Plus at $20 per month, which gives you access to image and video generation at up to 720p resolution and 10-second duration.

For heavier use, ChatGPT Pro at $200 per month offers higher resolution (up to 1080p), longer clips of up to 20 seconds, faster generations, and watermark-free downloads, with support for 5 concurrent tasks.

**My Observations**

Get Jim Clyde Monge’s stories in your inbox
-------------------------------------------

Join Medium for free to get updates from this writer.

It’s been a while since OpenAI released Sora, and the video quality is starting to lag behind newer competitors. Still, it’s a good tool — especially if you’re already a ChatGPT Plus subscriber since it comes included at no extra cost. The ability to generate up to 20-second clips is also a big advantage compared to most models, capped at 5 or 8 seconds.

### 6. Hailuo AI 02

The latest version of Hailuo brings a level of physical realism and charm that you don’t normally expect from a budget-friendly AI video model.

This version of Hailuo uses frame-by-frame physics simulation and attention-mapped motion prompts. That means when you describe something strange or highly specific, the model actually tries to anchor it in real-world behavior.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 13: Hailuo AI homepage. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*Uc_4VZyoayt0hdcqakA5DA.png)

Hailuo AI homepage. Image by 

For our coffeeshop video example, let’s use the same prompt to generate a video with Hailuo 02.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 14: Hailuo AI video generator dashboard. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*SgaHiJX7uPbJTgPd6Tsa4g.png)

Hailuo AI video generator dashboard. Image by 

Here’s the final result:

Hailuo AI video output. Image by 

**Pricing**

Hailuo offers four subscription tiers:

*   Standard at $14.99 per month with 1,000 credits and single-task generation
*   Pro at $54.99 per month with 4,500 credits, 10-second videos, and two concurrent tasks
*   Master at $119.99 per month with 10,000 credits and the same limits as Pro, butwith more usage capacity
*   Ultra at $124.99 per month with 12,000 credits plus unlimited use of the older Hailuo 01 model.

All plans support 1080p and max out at 10 seconds per generation.

**My Observations**

Hailuo 02 is incredibly cheap to run — you can generate a full video for as little as $0.25. The trade-off is that it doesn’t support native audio yet, which limits its use for polished projects. I really hope MiniMax adds audio support in future versions while keeping the pricing as affordable as it is now.

### 7. Pika Labs

Pika is a generative AI platform that lets you create videos from text or image input. It isn’t new to the AI video scene — Pika was co-founded by Demi Guo and Chenlin Meng, former PhD students at Stanford University’s Artificial Intelligence Lab, with a vision to revolutionize video creation through AI.

One of its most popular features is Pikaeffects, which makes it fun and simple to play around with videos without complex prompting. You can inflate, crush, squish, melt, and more, giving your clips a unique and creative touch.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 15: Pika Labs homepage. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*GJiKnCMiyMmNTbiF1tl2xQ.png)

Pika Labs homepage. Image by 

Using the coffee shop at sunset prompt, Pika generated a warm and lively scene. Here’s the final video:

Pika Labs sample output. Image by 

**Pricing**

Pika offers four plans:

*   Free with 80 credits per month
*   Standard at $10 per month with 700 credits
*   Pro at $35 per month with 2,300 credits
*   Fancy at $95 per month with 6,000 credits

All paid tiers remove watermarks, allow commercial use, and unlock faster generations with access to all model versions and Pikaffects. Yearly plans are 20% cheaper.

**My observation**

I will say this: while Pika may not always match the ultra-high realism of Veo or Kling, it handles photorealism, physics, and dynamic camera movements better than many tools in this price range. And for creators who value playfulness and experimentation, Pika is honestly one of the most enjoyable tools to work with.

### 8. Midjourney Video

MidJourney introduced its video model just a couple of months ago. It took them years to roll it out since, unlike bigger players like Google and OpenAI, MidJourney doesn’t have the same level of resources.

Still, when it launched, the response from fans was positive.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 16: Midjourney editor. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*z-GTV3c3Zry6NlKjuWNxnQ.png)

Midjourney editor. Image by 

Using the same prompt for our girl at the coffee shop video, this is what I got from Midjourney video:

Midjourney video sample output. Image by 

One of the standout qualities is how the videos preserve the unique style and aesthetics that made MidJourney images so popular. It feels like watching MidJourney art come alive in motion.

**Pricing**

MidJourney offers three main plans:

*   Basic at $10 per month with ~200 image generations, SD video support, and one concurrent fast video job.
*   Standard at $30 per month with 15 hours of fast generations, SD video, and three concurrent video jobs.
*   Pro at $60 per month with 30 hours of fast generations, both SD and HD video support, and up to six concurrent fast video jobs, plus unlimited relaxed video and image generations.

Yearly plans are 20% cheaper.

**My Observations**

What I like about MidJourney Video is that it sticks to its own aesthetics instead of chasing photorealism. The dreamy, artistic vibe is still there — it just moves now. From a developer’s perspective, I’d love to see MidJourney eventually open their video and image models to a public API since access is still locked down. In terms of quality, the results are impressive, but realism and camera control could definitely improve in future updates.

### 9. Adobe Firefly

Adobe Firefly is Adobe’s generative AI platform that includes text-to-video capabilities alongside its image tools.

With Firefly, you can generate animations, cinematic looks, or even claymation-style outputs in just a few clicks. It also integrates smoothly with Adobe’s ecosystem, so you can add generated effects like smoke, fire, or lens flares into your projects in Premiere Pro or After Effects.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 17: Adobe Firefly homepage. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*06WHXkfFOSv_ACWCkGggBA.png)

Adobe Firefly homepage. Image by 

Where Firefly really stands apart is in its **copyright and safety policies**. Unlike most AI video models trained on scraped internet data, Firefly is trained only on licensed sources like Adobe Stock and public domain content where copyright has expired. That makes its outputs commercially safe, meaning you can use them confidently in professional projects without worrying about copyright disputes.

Using the coffee shop at sunset prompt, Firefly generated a clip that leaned surprisingly toward a cartoon or stylized look, even though I didn’t specifically ask for that.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 18: Adobe Firefly video generator. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*xGttk_B9SGXemXWu2wKUFQ.png)

Adobe Firefly video generator. Image by 

Here’s the final video:

Adobe Firefly video output. Image by 

**Pricing**

Firefly has three paid tiers:

*   Standard at $10.50 per month (about 2,000 credits, roughly 20 five-second videos)
*   Pro at $32 per month (7,000 credits, around 70 five-second videos)
*   Premium at $215 per month (50,000 credits, enough for larger-scale video and audio projects).

All plans include 100 GB of cloud storage and full access to the latest Firefly models.

**My Observations**

It was strange that Firefly produced cartoon-style videos even without asking for a stylized output. Still, if copyright safety is your main concern, Firefly is easily the best choice. You know the videos are safe to use commercially, which gives them an edge over most competitors.

### 10. Vidu

Vidu is powered by a proprietary architecture called the Universal Vision Transformer (U-ViT), which combines diffusion and transformer models. This hybrid design allows it to generate high-quality videos with smooth camera movements, detailed facial expressions, and realistic lighting and shadows.

Vidu first introduced this technical framework back in 2022, making it one of the pioneers in the space.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 19: Vidu AI homepage. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*-CAPC8FN0NUBfHuPdUl3GQ.png)

Vidu AI homepage. Image by 

To generate a video, select one of the video generation modes in the dashboard. Vidu supports: reference to video, image to video, and text to video. As an example, let’s try to generate a video using our girl at the coffee shop prompt.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 20: Vidu AI video generator. Image by Jim Clyde Monge](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*SVj6PVH-HznsOB9gA4gV1g.png)

Vidu AI video generator. Image by 

After a few seconds, here’s the final result:

Vidu AI video sample. Image by 

Cool. There’s not much movement in the camera, but the expression on her face and how the light illuminates through the room is impressive.

**Pricing**

Vidu offers a free plan with 10 references per month, while paid plans start at $10 per month for 800 credits (about 200 videos).

*   The Premium plan at $35 per month includes 4,000 credits for up to 1,000 videos, faster generation speeds, and early feature access.
*   For heavier users, the Ultimate plan at $99 per month provides 8,000 credits, unlimited off-peak generation, ultra-fast processing, and 300 references per month.

All plans support high-resolution 8-second video generation, watermark-free downloads, and commercial use. Yearly subscriptions are 20% cheaper.

### Final Thoughts

Personally, I prefer platforms that support multiple video models in one place. It saves me the hassle of juggling multiple subscriptions and lets me switch between models depending on the project. For most of my work, I use Pollo AI because of its flexibility. But there are times when I need a platform for something very specific. For example, when I’m generating UGC-style content, Invideo AI is usually my go-to since it’s built for that use case.

Some tools also stand out because of the creative controls they offer. Runway’s Aleph, for instance, is a fresh approach that lets you reimagine an existing video into something entirely new, giving more room for experimentation. Pika Labs has its own spin with Pika Effects, which adds playful animations and special effects that make videos feel less generic and more alive. Features like these are the kind of details that can make or break your workflow, depending on what you’re creating.

At the end of the day, there’s no single “best” AI video generator. Each platform has strengths that fit different situations, and what works for me might not work the same way for you. That’s why I suggest exploring these tools yourself and testing them with your own projects.

See which ones give you the results you’re after. And if you know of any platforms that deserve a spot on this list, I’d be glad to hear about them.

_Experience ChatGPT-Like Models Running Completely Offline! In Your Browser!_

Ever wondered what it would feel like to use cutting-edge language models inside your browser?

Locally, privately, and even offline — without ever sending a byte of your data to a remote server?

Buckle up: the future of privacy-first AI isn’t just coming, it’s live, open-source, and astonishingly easy to use.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 5](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*wXqB3d6NaJfa9WCaUgmx0w.png)

Hi, this is Jannis.

Let me walk you through what makes the “in-browser-llm-inference” project so compelling — and why it might just be the turning point for developers, builders, and creators seeking true control over their AI.

What is Private In-Browser LLM Inference?
-----------------------------------------

Most web-based chatbots and AI assistants, even the most celebrated ones, perform their heavy lifting (inference) remotely on powerful company servers.

Enter “in-browser-llm-inference” — a project that completely flips the script. Here, all inference happens within your own browser, using your computer’s CPU.

The entire process, from loading the model to generation, never leaves your device.

I know I know… I am the one who wrote a alot about MCP servers lately and praised about this.

No doubt, MCP servers are one of the best way to align your task by connecting with correct tool.

okay I am not explaing again what is MCP server is? I have already wrote a detailed article on it few months back. If you want to know all about MCP sever, then you can check this article.

Using Gemini CLI to Create a Gemini CLI Config Repo
===================================================

[![Image 17: Dazbo (Darren Lester)](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:32:32/1*jFg7mJ4-yYxt5agy4MwpyQ.jpeg)](http://medium.com/@derailed.dash?source=post_page---byline--519399e25d9a---------------------------------------)

[Dazbo (Darren Lester)](http://medium.com/@derailed.dash?source=post_page---byline--519399e25d9a---------------------------------------)

Follow

7 min read

·

Aug 12, 2025

[](http://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fvote%2Fgoogle-cloud%2F519399e25d9a&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2Fgoogle-cloud%2Fusing-gemini-cli-to-create-a-gemini-cli-config-repo-519399e25d9a&user=Dazbo+%28Darren+Lester%29&userId=58a0bd8ba726&source=---header_actions--519399e25d9a---------------------clap_footer------------------)

268

[](http://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fbookmark%2Fp%2F519399e25d9a&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2Fgoogle-cloud%2Fusing-gemini-cli-to-create-a-gemini-cli-config-repo-519399e25d9a&source=---header_actions--519399e25d9a---------------------bookmark_footer------------------)

[Listen](http://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2Fplans%3Fdimension%3Dpost_audio_button%26postId%3D519399e25d9a&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2Fgoogle-cloud%2Fusing-gemini-cli-to-create-a-gemini-cli-config-repo-519399e25d9a&source=---header_actions--519399e25d9a---------------------post_audio_button------------------)

Share

This is a really trivial but useful example of how you can use Gemini CLI to execute development workflows for you.

![Image 18](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:600/1*oUDUEupIr9htikYd8BE70w.gif)

Video generated using Veo3

Context
-------

I’m using Gemini CLI — and Google Code Assist in Agent Mode — on three different devices at home. Since I’m often tweaking my global Gemini CLI configuration and then having to replicate that configuration to the other machines, I figured it was time to create a private GitHub repo to manage my configuration.

Admittedly, this is a trivial task. But I wanted to demonstrate how useful Gemini CLI is at doing this sort of thing.

Let’s get to it!

Initial Gemini Configuration and Pre-Reqs
-----------------------------------------

I’ve created a git repo from my `~/.gemini` folder. This folder contains a bunch of stuff that I want to track, as well as stuff I don’t want to track.

`(tree -L 2 --dirsFirst -a -F)`

.gemini/

├── commands/

│ └── plan.toml

├── history/

│ └── stuff-i-dont-care-about

├── tmp/

│ └── stuff-i-dont-care-about

|

├── .env

├── .gitattributes

├── GEMINI.md

├── google_accounts.json

├── installation_id

├── oauth_creds.json

└── settings.json
### My Gemini Context

My `GEMINI.md` provides the global context that I want Gemini CLI to follow:

# Project: Dazbo's Global Gemini Configuration

---

This configuration should apply to all Gemini CLI invocations, unless any particular rules are overridden by a more local rule.

---

## General Instructions:

- You are speaking to Dazbo, so feel free to occasionally use the name.

- My GitHub handle is derailed-dash.

- When running Python tools, prefer to use uvx where possible.

- When installing Python dependencies, prefer uv and ensure you are installing to a virtual environment.

- If a new dependency is required, please state the reason.

## Mandatory Tooling

To ensure Python code adheres to required standards, the following commands  **must**  be run before creating or modifying any `.py` files. These commands will automatically fix many common issues and flag any that require manual intervention. The commands must be run from the root of the project:

1. **Check and fix linting issues:**

 ```bash

 uvx ruff@latest check --fix .

 ```

2. **Format the code:**

 ```bash

 uvx ruff@latest format .

 ```
### My Settings

The `settings.json` is my Gemini configuration:

{

 "theme": "GitHub",

 "selectedAuthType": "oauth-personal",

 "checkpointing": {"enabled": true},

 "mcpServers": {

 // --- Using remote GitHub MCP server ---

 "github": {

 "httpUrl": "https://api.githubcopilot.com/mcp/",

 "headers": {

 "Authorization": "${GITHUB_GEMINI_CLI_PAT}"

 },

 "timeout": 5000

 },

 "veo": {

 "command": "mcp-veo-go",

 "env": {

 "MCP_REQUEST_MAX_TOTAL_TIMEOUT": "240000",

 "MCP_SERVER_REQUEST_TIMEOUT": "30000",

 "GENMEDIA_BUCKET": "${GOOGLE_STORAGE_BUCKET}",

 "PROJECT_ID": "${GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT}",

 "LOCATION": "${GOOGLE_CLOUD_REGION}"

 }

 },

 "imagen": {

 "command": "mcp-imagen-go",

 "env": {

 "MCP_SERVER_REQUEST_TIMEOUT": "55000",

 "GENMEDIA_BUCKET": "${GOOGLE_STORAGE_BUCKET}",

 "PROJECT_ID": "${GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT}",

 "LOCATION": "${GOOGLE_CLOUD_REGION}"

 }

 },

 "chirp3-hd": {

 "command": "mcp-chirp3-go",

 "env": {

 "MCP_SERVER_REQUEST_TIMEOUT": "55000",

 "GENMEDIA_BUCKET": "${GOOGLE_STORAGE_BUCKET}",

 "PROJECT_ID": "${GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT}",

 "LOCATION": "${GOOGLE_CLOUD_REGION}"

 }

 },

 "lyria": {

 "command": "mcp-lyria-go",

 "env": {

 "MCP_SERVER_REQUEST_TIMEOUT": "55000",

 "GENMEDIA_BUCKET": "${GOOGLE_STORAGE_BUCKET}",

 "PROJECT_ID": "${GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT}",

 "LOCATION": "${GOOGLE_CLOUD_REGION}"

 }

 },

 "avtool": {

 "command": "mcp-avtool-go",

 "env": { 

 "MCP_SERVER_REQUEST_TIMEOUT": "55000",

 "PROJECT_ID": "${GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT}",

 "GENMEDIA_BUCKET": "${GOOGLE_STORAGE_BUCKET}",

 "LOCATION": "${GOOGLE_CLOUD_REGION}"

 }

 },

 "gas_web_apps": {

 "command": "npx",

 "args": [

 "-y",

 "mcp-remote", // Run npm install -g mcp-remote 

 "https://script.google.com/macros/s/AKfycbyey_zJ66yIv191UmJSeikrkZhwmU3COzTq3h7rXQG3NZZkULiKV8EcnTtZQWs2bZ89/exec?accessKey=${DAZBO_APPS_SCRIPTS_ACCESS_KEY}"

 ],

 "env": {}

 }

 },

 "excludeMCPServers": ["lyria", "gas_web_apps"] // list of MCP servers to exclude

}
In this file I’ve enabled checkpointing and added a bunch of MCP servers in order to interact with GitHub, AVtool (e.g. to facilitate interaction with `ffmpeg`), and Google media generation (e.g. Imagen, Veo, etc). I’ve also disabled a couple of MCP servers, just for faster startup. I’ll enable them when I need them.

### Custom Slash Commands

I’ve added a single custom command: `/plan`. I got this idea from 

[Romin Irani](https://medium.com/u/802a4d428d95?source=post_page---user_mention--519399e25d9a---------------------------------------)

’s article [here](http://medium.com/google-cloud/gemini-cli-tutorial-series-part-7-custom-slash-commands-64c06195294b).

Using Gemini CLI / Code Assist To Do The Rest
---------------------------------------------

I’ve been using Gemini CLI from the terminal a lot lately. But for this demo I’ll be using **Gemini Code Assist in Agent Mode**. It is powered by Gemini CLI and leverages your Gemini CLI configuration and tools, if you’ve configured them. I’m using the Gemini Code Assist extension in Visual Studio Code.

### Create a .gitignore

First task: I want to create a `.gitignore`.

> Please create a .gitignore file for me. In my repo I only want to track GEMINI.md, settings.json and the commands directory.

![Image 19](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:618/1*rOP40aDCSD_bQQy_WPghUQ.png)

.gitignore created!

I didn’t love the first result. It was set to ignore everything by default, and then explicitly added some things to include. To be fair, it *is* what I asked for. But I’d rather not do it this way.

> Please change the .gitignore so that it doesn’t start with the “ignore everything”. Just explicitly ignore the things we don’t want to track.

![Image 20](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:631/1*s8BpOSJy8y3VgxNYNxoTFw.png)

The resulting `.gitignore` is what I wanted:

# Ignore directories

/history/

/tmp/

# Ignore files

google_accounts.json

installation_id

oauth_creds.json
### Create a README

Every repo needs a `README.md`, obviously!

> Please create a readme

![Image 21](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:626/1*n3ZWA_hN1OowA9rdZp1-gA.png)

Create a readme

And so it does:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 22](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*Q7bReGHeO6ohM-rtVMxgRg.png)

README.md created

I then added some additional info to this starter-for-10 `README.md`.

### Create the GitHub Repo

> I want to push this git repo as a new private GitHub repo called “Dazbo-Gemini-Config”. Please plan how you will do this, and then we will execute.

![Image 23](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:640/1*M5d6ngrqYyWByNO0RCo0gA.png)

The GitHub Plan

This looks pretty good. The agent has determined it should use the GitHub MCP tool to the work.

Get Dazbo (Darren Lester)’s stories in your inbox
-------------------------------------------------

Join Medium for free to get updates from this writer.

Subscribe

Subscribe

But hang on… I’ve already checked in those two files.

> Yes, but I think I’ve already committed those two files

The agent checks:

![Image 24](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:612/1*CrznuIOezh_lYMjOpPaFqA.png)

Checking commits

And it concludes:

![Image 25](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:617/1*PMaX9PG_lbyI1rtTNVmMmQ.png)

Git commit conclusin

So now we can execute the plan:

![Image 26](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:628/1*tqEqvJdHgXRxfySQIbjDsA.png)

Execute the GitHub repo plan

Ooh, an error.

![Image 27](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:635/1*Zo4czpNcjbhOJWksiMP6vw.png)

Branch name issue

It turns out that it’s tried to push to a remote branch called `main` but my local branch is called `master`. It offers to push `master` instead, but I’d rather rename the local to `main`.

> Actually, can we rename the local branch to main?

![Image 28](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:623/1*FGnY1TQfWpbazqiFFMmVag.png)

And it’s done! The new private repo has been created in GitHub!

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 29](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*T767oytqxoXndWflkaAPZA.png)

Repo in GitHub

Using This Config on Another Machine
------------------------------------

Okay, my Gemini CLI configuration is now safely stored in GitHub. But what if I want to now apply this configuration on another machine _where I already have Gemini CLI installed?_ I.e. where I already have a `~/.gemini` folder?

I’m on such a machine now. So let’s ask Gemini CLI!

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 30](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1000/1*U2oA_nv_Mh_O0L4wlwNSGA.png)

How to sync the GitHub repo into my current folder

So Gemini CLI tells us the plan:

1.   Initialise the local `~/.gemini` folder as a git repo
2.   Connect the GitHub repo as the remote
3.   Pull the remote

Let’s execute the plan:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 31](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1000/1*-B21Xzeg46nG-wXFCc7bmg.png)

Connecting and fetching from the remote

Of course, some of the files being fetched already exist in the local directory, so this happens:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 32](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1000/1*1Gd16N3yHrPs0k17AYPQ6g.png)

Warning: we’re going to overwrite

At this point I took a copy of these files… Just in case. And then I authorised Gemini CLI to overwrite them:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 33](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1000/1*vK1nRASLt9kyxJv1PqnkSg.png)

Overwrite the local files

And we’re done! Gemini CLI is now configured on this device exactly as it was on my other device.

If we ever want to repeat this on another machine, we can just run these commands:

# From our ~/.gemini folder

git init # Initialise this folder as a git repo

git remote add origin https://github.com/derailed-dash/Dazbo-Gemini-Config

git fetch # Retrieve the remote

git reset --hard origin/main # Force overwrite of local with main branch
Conclusions
-----------

I’ve used Gemini CLI / Google Code Assist in Aghttpent Mode to:

*   Create my `.gitignore`
*   Create my `README.md`
*   Create a new private GitHub repo and push my local to it

All with natural language prompts and not a single git command!

I can then use this new repo to ensure my Gemini CLI is configured consistently across my devices. I went ahead and synchronised this repo into an existing `~/.gemini` folder on another machine. Once again, I used natural language prompts to Gemini CLI to achieve this.

Sweet!

_Think traditional Kanban is powerful? Wait until you orchestrate armies of AI agents — and watch your coding workflow transform overnight._

Managing and organizing the output of multiple AI coding assistants is quickly becoming a superpower for builders, but juggling agents in chaotic windows or endless Slack threads?

That’s yesterday. Something smarter just arrived.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

![Image 5](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/0*0LeX0P89c42RaFtd)

Hi, this is Jannis.

If you’re like me, you’ve probably wondered if there’s a tool that keeps your growing fleet of AI coding agents on track, lets you switch between them in seconds, and still gives you a global birds-eye view over what’s done, in progress, or blocked.

That’s exactly what I set out to dig into when I found **Vibe Kanban.**A Kanban board designed for orchestrating coding agents. 

If you’re experimenting solo, building an MVP for your SaaS, or shipping consistently in a team, stay with me.

> Before we dive in, let’s set some foundation. Kanban is an agile method to organize projects. Have you heard of scrum or kanban or other methodologies before, or do you already use them? 
>
